fields.Title of Presentation: Integrating Science and Adaptation Policy: The Effects of Uncertainty on Coastal Housing Markets
fields.Conference/Meeting Name: Association of Environmental and Resource Economists Annual Meeting
fields.Sponsoring Organization: Association of Environmental and Resource Economists
fields.Description/Abstract: Integration of science into policy is a primary challenge for climate change adaptation. Yet, when communication of climate science signals a potential policy without concurrent political action, the economic incentives created by that uncertainty may have unintended consequences. We examine the effect on housing starts resulting from a scientific report by a regulatory agency urging coastal communities in North Carolina, USA to consider sea-level rise when making new land-use policies. This signal resulted in temporal leakage of development decisions, as landowners responded by increasing new housing construction by 27\% in coastal counties to avoid future development constraints. We then show these effects are larger for parcels with high sea-level rise risk exposure, with housing starts increasing up to 59\% initially and remaining elevated after nullification of the policy signal. This green paradox in climate adaptation planning implies that up to \$654 million of additional housing was constructed in North Carolina locations vulnerable to sea-level rise that would not have been built otherwise.
